The electrical potential of the Earth rises around 100V with every meter from the ground, but that potential depends a lot on geolocation, radio stations, etc. This means: the height of the rocket*100V = the result of the electric potential.

We all know that the highest electrostatic charge occurs at the very tip of an object (in our case, the spike of the rocket). I assume that the DSLR sensor interfered with that electromagnetic radiation or the radiation distorted the visible spectrum of light. It would be much easier to explain with a drawing, but it is not unknown that strong electrostatic radiation of certain frequencies can bend light.

5:47 "Why is there a line on my lunar eclipse photos?" That’s because you photographed a trail left by a plane in the background. It was there before, but you couldn’t detect it until the moon landed BEHIND it. The moonlight came from behind the trail, so the trail appears as an obstacle to the moonlight. The light of the sun (sky), on the other hand, also illuminates the trail from the front, making it more difficult to detect. The trail just happened to be just the right height. You would have noticed it by lowering or raising your crane basket.

My guess is that you reproduced Henri Becquerel's experiment discovering radioactivity.
There must be a lightning rod at the top of the rocket. In the mid 20th century, they used to be radioactive, to increase electrical conductivity of the surrounding atmosphere. Although these ligthning rod should not be used anymore, it could explain this line.
The camera can be a bit sensible to radioactivity and the particles coming from the top of the rod may scramble its receptor. Then, i guess the camera has an error correcting software which, for some reason, smooth the error on the pixels of the same row. So this line is an artifact from the error correcting sotware of the camera.
If my guess is right, you should be able to reproduce this phenomenon in similar condition. Finding a radioactive lightning rod should be hard theses days, so you'll have to find some other source of radioactivity. Then, take pictures of it with the same camera, same luminosity, same angular opening and maximal resolution. You'll maybe have to adapt the distance to the expected radioactivity of the source. @SmarterEveryDay Not sure if after all this time you're still looking for an answer, but it is most likely an interference phenomenon. The conditions (parallel light, long observation distance, small light source, only slight variations in wavelength) are just perfect for it. What I think happened is that you unintentionally created a doubleslit experiment and recorded one of it's minima. The Intensity of the double slit (for symmetrical slits) is proportional to cos^2(π⋅d⋅sin(α)/λ), where d is the slit distance and α the observation angle. With your α being extremely small and basically constant due to the large distance to the rocket(it is definetly not =0 due to small orientation variations of the camera), the sharp tip width leads to slight variations in d, so at one height it should match the condition of d*α=λ even if it's width is on the order 10^-2 m which would lead to low intensity. The real math would be more complicated due to unsymetrical, changing slit widths and those widths being dependent on the observation distance to the rocket, but the gist is the same.

5:02 Just a thought, but my best guess would be that this is an example of atmospheric refraction induced by a cold front on top of a warmer front that just happened to line up in the right spot at the top of the rocket. If you take a closer look, you can see that the "edges" of the moon are slightly deformed at that line. It's almost as if the bottom section of the moon was cut off and moved slightly higher than it should be. If the temperature of the air under the line was slightly warmer than the temperature above the one (and not a gradient, but isolated fronts), then the change in air density would appear to make the bottom of the moon slightly higher than rest of the moon. The line stays in relative position to the light on the rocket and the viewer as the moon descends. The source of the phenomenon is the rocket light. Light is a wave of particles (photons) that pass through the lens of the rocket light (lens) and diffracts (splitting up). The geometry of the lens also causes the waves that are split to be out of phase from each other and as the light travels to the viewer, the opposite phased wave lengths of light collide canceling each other out. The light goes dark. The comment from J War is on point.

Noise cancellation acts the same way.

This line could be a gravity wave known in atmospheric science - not to confuse with gravitational waves known from astronomy.

The layered atmosphere has certain regeions with strong density changes along the vertical direction (e.g. the boundary layer). These changes can allow surface waves to propagate and even to break - very similar to the waves you see on the water surface. These waves are called gravity waves because the reacting force is the earths gravitation.

So if you look along such a surface in the atmosphere - what is very likely to be the case under these shallow angles - light will be refracted and seen from elsewhere but the expected background. On a evenly distributed layer this effect will not be visible, because it affacts all the lightrays equally. But with the presence of a gravity wave a anomaly is introduced that makes this phenomen visible.

Just a speculation from an atmospheric scientist. Nice video by the way!

What you seem to be dealing with here is a phenomenon explainable with two monochromatic light sources and a polarization filter on the camera. (ND filter or Circular). One source of monochromatic light is the moon. When the moon is high at night it is reflecting the light of the sun and is not monochromatic. But low on the horizon the atmosphere filters out most other frequencies. The other source of monochromatic light is not so obvious. If the rocket is illuminated with Low Pressure Sodium flood lights. those are also mostly light of one wavelength..Then the camera is seeing mostly just two frequencies of light. This can create a cancellation interference of a single horizontal line if a polarization filter is set just right

This line is being caused by a natural phenomenon of light of the moon being reflected by the atmosphere. Two different layers of air of different temperature caused by weather fronts can refract light (from the moon) and show a thin dark ridge or line. The line is located at the location of the different layers of air.  This dark line is visible at the bottom edge (facing the earth) of rainbows. The natural light is bent (refracted) by raindrops and the sky is darker below the rainbow. On the moon photo the line is visible once the moon is low enough to backlight it.

I would say, an optical effect and/or digital artefact.
Gut feeling, it feels like an Anti-Aliasing Bug (for a terribly inaccurate terminology to describe it :D
Chips and screens take and display lines of colour. So rendering thin lines diagonally causes pixels to render in their grid.

Anti-aliasing smooths out your binary grid pixels colours (giving jagged lines), and spreads them over pixels multiple pixels, smoothing out the effect.
As algorithms and hardware have evolved there has been varying anti-aliasing technics.
But they always have to sample the incoming pixel information first.

Since you have Both Foreground and background, the optics are doing their thing and the sensor is doing it's thing. And for the majority of cases, it's not a problem.
With just a few pixels of data to sample and smooth, the software should be able to discern what is going on, (foreground and background) and it's back to normal.

The effect only kicks in at the point, (oh, err, pun intend...ed ? apparently? ) of transition.

So the point being...(darn it) is at the point of contact, there are fewer pixels at the tip to work with. The moon and the rocket are showing similar colour pallet, to work with, and then we have a blinking light (sorry these puns are just writing themselves), throwing in additional contrasting information at that area of limited information to distinguish what belongs to what Rocket or moon background / Foreground. And so the rest of the scan-line carries that digital decision over the rest of the scan line.

there are some unfounded assumptions that have been made concerning this line by the person who made this video. firstly it is assumed the line is caused by the tip of the rocket or at least the object on the tip of the rocket which then eliminates any other possibility. secondly it is assumed it is not a contrail caused by an aircraft because there were no aircraft in the area at the time. at that angle of photography which is almost at a tangent to the earth, that contrail @ 30,000' will be many many miles away, maybe 60 - 100, (someone else can do the math on that for a more accurate figure). it only shows up under the high magnification of a high quality photographic lens and would not be seen by the naked eye, the fact it falls inline with the tip of the rocket is simply an anomalous coincidence. the contrail would never be seen at that distance even with a high quality lens before the sun comes up to shine on it and the fact it stays with the tip of the rocket is because the contrail, rocket and observer are all locked together with the rotation of the earth and it is the moon that 'moves through' the field of view. i would suggest that if the observer were somewhat to the right or left of the rocket tip - moon alignment the line would still be there. also if the observers height were adjusted back/ forward - up/down then the line would also be above or below the rocket tip. also the fact that the line is not horizontal should at the very least ring alarm bells when considering any sort of refractive anomaly concerning the rocket tip. that's just what i see anyway.

refraction and sometimes reflection (obscured reflection plane actually). GA pilots see several of those as they climb through the layers of smoke, smog, thin cloud layers, etc. They always seem to have a "reference" source, such as the wingtip outside, an object between you and some distant fix, and similarly, the tip of your rocket.  This reference source makes it appear that these "lines" are emanating from some object.  The closer you are in RELATIVE (think parallax) altitude to the source of refraction (or sometimes reflection), the thinner the line is.  The length of the line is dependent on the source of light being refracted.  Wide backlight (and obscuring 'surface'), wide line (remember to account for parallax in this).

This is a diffraction meniscus or node point where two atmospheres of air meet but will not mix (for many reasons including moisture level and temperature). The meeting point between the atmospheres creates a diffraction point where light bends acting like a distortion lense such as seen in some mirage photos.  They are usually horizontal due to gravity and density and invisible to the naked eye unless observed in a distant mirage or zoomed-in on a large illuminated background like the moon.  It happens to be almost aligned up with the tip of the rocket, I say 'almost' because it is slightly below the tip and not perfect.

It was a power line that you couldn't see between you and the rocket. The moon being there illuminated/gave it a back drop to show up. Nothing showed up on the other camera because of the slightly different angle and height difference.

The fact it is parallel with the top of the frame suggests it could be an auto-iso issue caused by the sudden contrast, if the camera is using a rolling shutter, it will see light, then a thin strip of dark at the tip of the rocket, then light again, that sudden change could be causing it to adjust the ISO, over compensate, create a bright line, then over compensate the other way on the next scan line, causing a dark line on the left hand side of the image (just using left hand roll as an example) then it passes over the dark spot, again, but does not pick it up this time, and continues with a dark line, then when it gets to the next lline, it has had enough time to react that it sorts itself out for the rest of the image.

Anyway that's what I think is going on there.

Possible answer (2020) I am an 10+ year expirience optician, an think it is camera artefact. A rare combination of circumstances has occurred. There was a rather long exposure time on the camera due to the dark time of day. At the time of the shot, the upper lantern was lit on a rocket, which had almost the same color as the moon behind it. The camera takes data from the sensor line by line, and apparently due to the appearance of a brighter lantern in the line, the sensitivity of this line of pixels aligned with the exposure time, as a result, the lantern turned out to be almost the same brightness as the moon in the background, but the line was darker. That is, this line is the result of processing pixels on a matrix in the camera.

I think it was caused by the angle of the sun beaming polarized light towards the moon, which is then reflected back to Earth. The tip of the rocket disrupts it enough to create a line parallel to the polarization. Measure that angle and get the angle minus 180 degrees that the light is reflected to you from the sun via the moon. Triangulate to figure out exactly how far away the sun is, given the already known distance to the moon. EDIT: btw you'll notice it in a lot of sun-setting videos. When the angle is less extreme, you'll see another similar effect where stemming from the point is a rounded extension that makes it look like the light is stretched a little.

By refraction of the earths atmosphere the super moon had a sufficiently narrow band of light waves (red-orange(600nm-625nm) cast onto it.  So, The light reflected back to us is also very narrow in wavelengths.   So the light that  passes through the optical  lens of the rocket beacon again refracts the light either higher or lower than the camera height..  Remember,  light of different wavelengths refract at specific  angles depending on the refractive index and shape of the medium its passing through.  In this case there are no other wavelengths available to refract to the height of the camera.   If the whole rocket ( and beacon) were to be oriented horizontally the line would have been vertical.     I don't think we're seeing an interference phenomenon  since we don't see any other specular noise like you see when you shine a laser onto a irregular shaped reflective surface.

Well, I am not sure if this helps, but here is what I believe just happened with your image. The two main camera manufacturers - Nikon & Canon used different sensors, obviously. Photographers may know that 'Nikon' cameras taken better images for landscapes and 'Canon' take better images for architecture (buildings). Why? it is to do with the way the algorithm within each make of camera works. Nikon sensors scan horizontally (great for landscapes) and Canon sensors scan vertically (great for buildings).  You will notice that the edges of the rocket are smooth whiles the edges of the moon are stepped due to the vertical scan been much efficient at following the vertical sides of the rocket but struggles with the edges of the moon.. This is because the Canon camera scan algorithm is able to detect the vertical rocket sides accurately until that vertical rocket edges disappears. It is at that precise point the scan algorithm changers to look for more vertical edges, but there are none. This produces a line of demarcation that is just visible on the moon background.

Back in 1996 I was out in the marsh area of Rotunda (Port Charlotte Florida) where I hunted and trapped wild hogs. One day I was checking my trap and noticed a pile of what looked like sand. I didn't think much of it at first but I thought it was odd that I never noticed it before. I came back by the pile that was about 6 feet tall (eye level) and was very fine and not sand but finely ground limestone rock. It had no silica sand and no sparkle. It had no stones, lumps, sand, roots, just a fine powder. The pile looked like it was in an hourglass with straight sides from top to bottom and all but perfectly round and covering leaves and small weeds and it also had a small palm tree that it had flowed around. You could see where the sides had flowed and cascaded from the top just like sand in an hourglass does. I dug around the edges and found that it was indeed on top of a layer of leaves all the way around. I did the math on a cone of material 6 feet tall and 12 feet wide and came up with 226.19 cubic feet and roughly 11 tons at about 100 lbs to a cubic foot which is what crushed limestone should weigh. I took a friend and a VHS video camera to document the strange find and I may still have a tape somewhere. But I could never figure out how that pile of fine stone powder could have been placed like that way out in the swamp where no vehicles could reach. I went back another time with a shovel in an attempt to dig to the bottom to see if the pile was covering something. I dug for over an hour trying to get to the bottom and I think I got over half way but this was a pretty big pile and it took a long time, so I had to quit. All I found was fine powdered limestone that would go through a window screen.
To this day I have no idea how 11 tons of fine rock powder gets piled up like that. I think I need to go back and look at it again and maybe get a sample.

If this was present in the photograph but not to the eye it would be reasonable to consider the camera technology. Digital camera sensors often have weird so-called "ISP programs" which apply post-process effects like photoshop does and also control feedback for sensor settings such as gain. It is reasonable to suspect that the ISP program uses various progressive brightness and contrast measures to adjust its post-processing and that the appearance of the first very intense pixels causes the program to apply an inappropriate post-process to a few lines until a new measure of the nature of the image has incorporated those bright pixels. It's also possible that a high-end camera controls gain on a line-by-line basis based on previous images before the one that is recorded and that the control program does something inappropriate at the first line with bright pixels, other options are that the sensor has an internal gain control or a readout artifact but I don't know so much about the extent of such features that might or might not be incorporated in sensors. You can test if it's something like these things by taking pictures with the camera at different angles around the optical axis - if the line rotates with the camera then it's sensor or ISP artifacts. If your camera has a raw bayer (or raw sensor) output file format then perhaps you can avoid the post-processes built into the camera as well.

It has been stated more or less already, but it is definitely an effect from the light on top of the rocket, combined with the exact viewing angle from the camera.


Specifically, this appears to be the rough equivalent of a lens flare, but in the atmosphere itself. Looking carefully, you can see an exaggerated lensing effect at the point of the line. Why is it not perfectly horizontal? That's likely because the atmosphere itself is at an angle relative to your position. The angle is then exaggerated in the same way that placing a stick into water at an angle not only makes it appear to be located in a different location, but also makes the angle of the stick appear to be more extreme than it is.


So what would make such an effect occur? I'm not 100% sure on this one, but I have a reasonable idea. The line is at its most clear when the tip of the rocket is in the brightest portion of the moon, and fades as moon moves and the rocket comes crosses the less bright portion. This indicates that it is in direct proportion to the volume of light crossing at this exact point and interacting with whatever that light is made from.


So, if we put all the elements of this analysis together, the likely conclusion is that there is a reflection you can not see occurring on the other side of the rocket. This reflection is creating an atmospheric lens flare which, because of its exact wavelength appears dark, rather than bright.

I suspect, that if a simultaneous photo(s), but on photographic film (old silver halide emulsion tech), were taken at the same time of your digital CCD recording, that the line would NOT appear on the developed Ag film, but only the digital image.  If so, then that absence of the line on Ag film would suggest that the digitally recorded line is an odd artifact of the digital recording CCD array system or the electronic processing of it.  Although that would not fully explain the (now-concluded-to-be-electronic) origin of the line, it would rule out an atmospheric effect.  Another experiment, though less definitive, would be to record with the original digital camera tilted at an angle to the horizon (angled thereby also to the natural horizontal stratification of many/most clouds). Would the lineremain parallel to th horizon, or be tilted to match the horizontal axis of the CCD array? When reflecting telescopes view stars, the support arms for the forward mirror disrupts the light making the stars appear to have points coming off of them. Perhaps, since the object blocking the light was further away and taking up less FOV than the light source, it created a line of darkness from the object rather than lines of light coming from the light source. I’d like to add that the number of support arms determines how many “rays” are in the final image (3 arms, 3 points; 5 arms, 5 points). Since the tip of the rocket was the blocking object, it would stand to reason that there would be only one line, or a series tiny dots that only look like a line

People have been photographing spires in front of the moon for many decades, without (as far as I know) anyone noticing any lines. That means that the effect is specific to this particular object.
In fact, it seems specific to the aircraft warning light on top of the rocket. Which will usually be a red glass cylinder with a rounded top, serving as a protective cover for the actual light source within. (Google "aviation obstruction light" and look at the images.)
So we have a reflective cylinder in the line of sight, reflections from which can create interference patterns in a plane perpendicular to the cylinder. I haven't been able to find a discussion of interference patterns off of reflective cylinders, but I'm willing to bet that's what we're seeing here: destructive interference due to reflected light. At high enough resolution, the line might even resolve into a series of light and dark bands.
Put a good telescope on that light housing, and I bet you'd see it tilted off of the vertical - that's why the line isn't perfectly horizontal.

I know what this is. This line is a reflection of your rocket, badly mis-formed and stretch in a plane that your line of sight is almost perfectly lies in. We know this is a reflection, because the line is attached to the tip of the rocket. Imagine a big silver sphere. You are somewhere on that sphere, and a rocket sits on it with its tip. From your point of view on the sphere (within some limited radius from the contact point of rocket) you will see the rocket, and a flattened reflection of it on the sphere, starting exactly where the rocket touches it. Flattened, because you are in that plane of the reflection or almost in it. So, this is a mirage. I predict a lighter band that is probably invisible with your equipment. A lighter band that encases the dark line, if I can say that. The cause of this mirage is atmospheric condition plus the solar light gradient in pen-umbral cone.

The day before the Rally, we were asked to join several other pro-life folks at the Christian radio station to do an interview. We knew in advance it could be a very long day, because that station was only licensed for 5 minutes of talk between music...so interviews were going to be spread out for quite some time. But God had a plan to make this happen in a different way. Just a few minutes before the interviews were to start, the station manager's wife called the radio station's wife to tell him she could no longer hear the station on the radio. A quick check of the equipment revealed that for reasons that remained unknow, the broadcast was indeed not going out. After some minutes of trying to diagnose the problem, and nothing coming from it, one of the other people there suggested that we all pray...so that is what we did. Everyone else prayed first, and when it got to me, though I normally did not pray this way at that time, but I chose to bind the principalities and powers of the air. Immediately after my prayer, though the equipment was still showing nothing was working, the station manager's wife called again and told him that she could hear the talking, but not the music. My first reaction was that this was a readout artifact, but you said you see it with direct imaging. So, just to get a feeling for things, I played with calculating a pathlength difference for a direct ray and a ray that diffracts around the edge of an object of width, d. Google maps shows the distance from the church to the rocket to be 3.5 km. It's reddish light, so let's call that 6e-7m wavelength. Mix that together and I need an object about d=3cm wide to get a half wavelength pathlength difference.  So, that is why this happens at the tip. Everything below the tip is too wide. As you go up, the obstruction width narrows until, at some point, it is just the right width to give the destructive interference. We have a spectrum of wavelengths, so this will be a smear of distance, vertically, so we get a narrow vertical band of height to serve as our obstruction.  The next question is, why do you get a band of darkness?  Somehow, that band is the locus of points of direct light canceling against the the diffracted light, but I haven't gotten a good, convincing diagram to see exactly how that is happening. But, my guts tell me it has to be a horizontal band because the diffraction is happening at a definite height (see above).  I'm not satisfied yet, but this seems to be a start.

I think it's from communications. Even if it's offline, an isolinear waveguide filter could cause a spectrum (or certain band) to become visible. We're communicating well above EHF, and idk how classified the THz bands are, but you have a "light" interceptor that's often placed behind the nosecones of these space program systems. In the late 80's we were transmitting enough data to be equivalent to 76 sets of encyclopedias every second. DC transmissions are just man's unnatural way of bending light-wave energy at specific frequencies for communication. We use this for a variety of "constantly on" systems, like Doppler radar systems, or even automatic landing systems for commercial aircraft.  Also, radio frequencies are sending constant signals.  These waves seek ground, and from what I've learned from electrical deratings (kinda like what's required for grounding rods)  . . . that high point in the air (the rocket), with a narrow tip & a waveguide filter are going to lead downward to plenty of free electrons.  There is a reason RC airplanes can be controlled, and it's not magic . . . it's "Science".  Picture that rocket as a huge upscaled RC plane & it's supposed to have the world's most sophisticated walkie-talkie on top.  Those signals that it interrupts never end. . . and it's just sitting there interrupting signal (aka light) like it's supposed to be doing. Now your camera captures a phenomenal event when that plane of communication is visibly able to be interrupted.  Do this, it might help get rid of the confusion. Take a piece of paper & write the words "Cell Phone" and "Doppler" and "Radio" and "Space-Talk" on it.  Then try flopping it up & down, but keeping it flat in the air (you might need to move it like a kite) then take a pencil & poke it through the bottom of the flat plane & say "rocket". That floppy paper is our light-wave transmissions (and that highway is getting over-packed) . . . well, the top of that rocket is able to listen . . . really good. So it breaks up some of the light & is seen as a dark line.  Keep this in mind, your cellphone does not "send" signal, it interrupts the signal. The power (heavy lifting) is done by transmission towers. When the signal is seen (broken up) on the other side, the difference is your voice. That's how the cellphone battery can last the better part of a day  . . . it's not charging up a huge field of energy & transmitting it into space like a trekkie communicator. Anyhow, off topic, but I hope that helps. At least, that's my best guess.

Hi,
this is Internet answering your question.

It is an artifact of the camera. Each time the xenon lamp flashes, the software detect an increase in brightness, so reduce the "exposure". After 2 or 3 scan lines, the xenon lamp is off, so the exposure is restored.
The software only check around the scan lines, so no correction is done in any other part of the image. Otherwise, you would see these darker horizontal lines repeating over the entire image.

Update please

I noticed immediately that the "line" is coincident with the bright light on the tip of the rocket. It is probably the brightest thing in the frame. Now, I do not know, so I am guessing here. Your camera is digital and that means that it captures the image more or less a pixel at a time. At least the image is composed of many horizontal lines of small pixel elements, and each of those is processed in series. I think. Now, suppose the camera has a some kind of exposure control. If so it will likely ramp up the "sensitivity" to capture the main scene. The main scene is not very bright. That bright spot might produce overexposed pixels compared to the rest of the moon. The spot maybe be large enough to subtend an area of 4 or more pixels. The camera software may process and correct sensitivity on a pixel by pixel basis, and if so, it would reduce the sensitivity of the pixels illuminated by the red light. Those pixel elements in the array would then not be "sensitive" enough to reproduce the moon light. Now if there is a rastering effect, scanning line by line, the software may think that the next pixels just outside the illuminated area need to be "dimmed" too. Depending on the timing of things, moreover, depending on the camera's internal programming, it may be creating a few horizontal lines of pixels that have reduced sensitivity and cannot capture the moon light at correct brightness. If so you end up with a line in your image.  It seems to me the camera should be designed to not do that, but this condition may be rare, and it could just be a "feature" they didn't quite program correctly.

Moon is dim, reddish.
Tower is brighter, nearly pure white.
Pixels in camera are in columns/rows...a row gets 'dazzled' by the contrast of the previous row, a dark line appears in the dim stuff.
Think about it like automatic gain control 'over-shoot'; a big signal makes the sensor dial down sensitivity at the expense of an already weak signal.
Or, to put it in a way that High School graduates in North America can understand: Aliens.

Also, which are the precise arguments against a contrail? Not seeing one after the sun came up isnt a great argument for instance; quite possible that the reddish backlight made visible what direct sunlight wouldnt.

I wouldn't bet against a genuine optical effect though... the light coming from a blood moon is pretty unusual in terms of its coherence properties. Note that all light interference (not counting entanglement) is of photons interfering with themselves. A blood moon photon wavefunction went around the earth on all sides, got seriously frequency-filtered, converged upon itself on the moon, reflected off, and then after some more atmosphere and lenses made it to your sensor. So its not just that the photons that you see are coming from around all sides of the earth; but each individual photon you observe comes around from all sides of the earth.

This long range coherence can produce some interesting effects. Everybody who has not fully understood laser speckles and the conditions under which you do and do not observe them (and that includes myself) should not preclude the possibility that there is something more interesting going on than just a contrail. And any failure to replicate that does not involve a two-way lightpath diffracting around a celestial -sized body isn't really a failure to replicate.

So unless someone can think of another clever way to replicate this big blue ball setup before then, seems like Jan. 21, 2019 will be the next possibility for serious attempts at replication!

Destin: The mysterious line is definitely not a light-sensor-caused or CCD-caused or computer-post-processing-caused effect, because it was observed through two separate DSLR still cameras, a video camera, and the naked eye.

Nor do I think it was any kind of refractive or diffractive effect. It was a single dark almost-horizontal (but not quite) band seen against the background of the moon. Refractive, diffractive, interference, and scattering effects tend not to look like that.

Nor was it something on or near the moon itself, as it stayed nearly motionless relative to the rocket.

Therefore, there are only two good candidates:

1. Power transmission line, either in-front-of or behind the rocket. Probably in front, quite close to you, else the altitude would be too high to be a transmission line. Would be invisible at night (black on black) until it got between you and the moon.

2. An airliner flew by, some miles away behind the rocket, a few minutes before Earth rotated to the point where the airliner's contrail (normally invisible at night) got between the Moon and you.

I'm voting for the airliner. They fly all over USA, 24/7, laying down contrails. At night, these contrails are usually invisible unless the Moon gets behind them. And there are hundreds of them in USA's skies at any one moment of time. And when you're looking at something 300 feet tall, from 60 feet elevation, from several miles away, you're looking horizontally across about 75 miles of sky, so it's very unlikely that their wouldn't be contrails between the moon and you as the moon sets.

Ironically, when I googled for saturn five rocket display huntsville I got the following image of the saturn five, a day-time image, with an airliner contrail on it, again not horizontal (they rarely are, because airliners travel in all directions, and unless they're traveling perpendicular to your line of site, the contrail will look non-horizontal):

https://media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-s/0e/2e/3c/97/saturn-v-outside.jpg

It's probably an artifact caused by the refresh rate of your CCD chip. CCD's refresh vertically, you see some pretty weird effects videoing spinning propellers and such like... but anything that moves vertically down or up will create effects on the CCD display..... Otherwise. I dunno.

Sensor electronics are a bit weird - It looks to me as if the sensor is reading the charge from the pixel at the tip of the rocket on the following pixels. Do you know if the sensor in your camera is CCD or CMOS?  You can google how the actual image is read from these two sensor types to see what I mean. CCD sensors can suffer from Blooming Effect (where pixel data from one pixel can spread in a horizontal line affecting pixels that are read next), and CMOS can have a rolling shutter effect, which appears more like two pictures spliced together horizontally. Its nice that you went through and documented all those steps to get the actual photo instead of just Photoshopping it.

It's the top of the glass/plastic cylinder. The walls of the cylinder are very thin, but from the moonlight's perspective the top of the cylinder would be at least a foot thick - but most importantly, the thickness would be continuously variable (because the light hitting the sides of the cylinder goes through less material). This could cause continuous diffraction along the plane of the disk (top of cylinder is a disk) which, because the moonlight is collinear, would cause interference. In this case, for some reason, it's destructive interference

It's line noise in the CCD/CMOS chip caused by the light on tip of the rocket saturating the sensor.  It's a pretty common artifact.  The light is bright and concentrated at a point source.  The moon behind it is also bright.  Between the 2, that particular pixel is saturated (maximum voltage).  The algorithms attempt to compensate for it and it creates a line across the sensor as the algorithms try to balance out the intensity.

Likely created a single line diffraction grating (in effect, a single line spectrophotometer).  Considering that the moon was very low on the horizon, the light traveling through the earth's atmosphere also acted as a lens, bending the wavelengths of light reflecting off the moon.  Thus the wavelengths of light right at the horizon were different from the wavelengths at the top, something that is not normally noticed.  At a long distance the Saturn rocket acted like a line in a diffraction grating and produced the right angle line at the tip.

Here's a theory...
When I was growing up, I lived near a Burger King that has a giant flag pole. At night, they would illuminate it with large flood lights from one side. On the opposite side, there was always an area of shadow that would point toward the sky. Because of light pollution from the surrounding business area, that shadow always created a very dark "shadow ray" in the sky.

So, I'm wondering if--while not a cable on the top of the Saturn V--might there be a VERY thin piece of material that was resulting in a VERY thin "shadow ray" in your field of view?

This would probably require a close view of the top of the rocket to see, but from your distance, the light of the Moon may have been creating a similar phenomenon.

That is a very bright Fresnel focused light beam.  It undoubtedly heats the atmosphere in a thin plane around the light, and it is cold there at night, so there will be a large temperature gradient that bends the light in a thin plane.  You can see the the light is actually not parallel to the horizon because the optical effect is at a slight tilt. If it were a camera artifact you would think it would be on a single row of pixels, but it is not.

I've done a lot of photography on an amateur level.  Personally, based on your clues, I'm convinced that this is the "star eater" algorithm in your 70D firmware that is creating that line.  You mentioned that you were looking through the lens at the time, so it couldn't have been anything to do with the sensor.  But, I'm not so sure that adds up.  I think your camera was detecting the beacon as an artifact, and was trying to delete it, and it bisected the moon with a line because the moon was also very bright, so it just kept going across.  I don't think the line is from the rolling shutter, because the line perfectly divides the moon.  They call it the star eater because it has been known to delete the brighter stars when taking photos of the night sky.  I searched the web for a similar example, but it's been a few years and I can't find results anymore.  But, I've seen it do this very thing, where it deletes an entire line across.

It could be a thermocline, similar to the Novaya Zemlya effect. Basically at ground level and up till just above tree level would have been one temperature, with a blanket of different-temperature air laying on top. Being elevated to just under the layer you would be photographing the Moon through a significant cross-section of that boundary, accentuating the tiniest refraction over the boundary into a visible artefact.

That is just my guess. I am not an atmospheric scientist, I just love the mysteries of this wonderful world we live in.

Hey Destin! I think the line on the moon is caused by what's called the pinspeck camera phenomenon, which is the opposite of a pinhole camera. The tip of the rocket (or possibly the warning light itself) is the speck in this case. While a pinhole camera creates an inverted image, a pinspeck camera creates an inverted shadow. In this case, since the light source is a crescent, we see an inverted crescent shadow. You can see that the line is faintly curved in the opposite direction of the crescent moon and is also flipped left/right. I believe there is also some distortion going on due to the fact that the rocket tip is not a perfect point.

- It is There if the light is on or off.
- It has not always the exact same relation to the Tip (in hight) if you look closely.
- It differs in thickness.
- It falls down away from sunset/heat source (not a meterologist sry).
- It has no reason to be a line if optical effect.
- It should be curcular if optical effect if no preffered direction.
- It is a "gas formation" if preferred direction.
- "gas formations" are clouds.

Breakdown of influence:
Lenses: no - any optical effect would be curcular
Source(moonlight): no - only position this was observed
Path of Light(Space): no - no Matter = no interaction (aaaaand would be curcular(/eliptical due to lensing through atmosphere entrance) blabla)
Path of light(Atmosphere): maybe - could be gas formations, like clouds.
Sensor of Cameras: no - would not have been visible through viewfinder
Mirror in Cameras: no - wouldnt be visible in picture

Christian verse Joel 2:31 is Hebrew verse Yo'el 3:4. I was thrown off for a bit while looking it up in my Tanakh.

Every now and then, Christians and Jews split the verses and chapters differently. For verses, it's often because in Latin and related languages, grammar doesn't permit sentence splits where the traditional Jewish cantillation indicates. (In Numbers 26:1, the cantillation even continues a Hebrew verse over a full paragraph break!) For chapters splits, the reason is less clear. For more than 2500 years, Jews did not number verses and chapters, until Gutenberg first printed his Bible. Like how Gutenberg split topics and imposed chapter splits onto the text, Jewish printers did the same, but they had a slightly different idea (tradition?) of where chapters should begin and end. Most of the breaks Jews use are the same as Gutenberg's, although very occasionally I see that the chapter breaks are different, aligning with the weekly Torah and Haftorah portion, or with the paragraph breaks in the Hebrew text, or sometimes for some other reason I can't discern.

For our verse in Joel, Hebrew verse 3:1 "And it will happen after this, that I will pour out My spirit..." comes after a gap in the line. That starts a "closed" paragraph (an "open" paragraph starts on a new line). It is true that of the two paragraph types, the closed paragraph is less disjunctive, (and even "open" paragraphs don't always start a new chapter,) but the phrase "And it will happen after this" means that some time will pass after the events in chapter 2 before the things described in chapter 3. Ultimately, only G-d knows what precisely will be in the End of Days, but I hope we'll see soon, and the prophet Elijah will explain all the confusing bits that remain.

Not sure what it is but here are some observations after looking at all the images in the video:

1. The black line is discernibly darker to the left of the tip of Saturn V than to the right.
2. There is a very very slight angle of the line that breaks exactly at the tip of Saturn V. Maybe 0.5 degrees. OR the line is slightly curved. I'm not sure which is correct.
3. The line is not parallel to the horizon, and the line is not perpendicular to Saturn V.
4. Where the line hits the moon edge there is a slight indentation.

My best current guess is that this is some optical artefact/phenomena related to using a camera lens in this exact setting and location with light sources behind and in front. Perhaps some sort of refraction effect. The curvature of the line could possibly be related to the roundness of the camera lens. The darker line on left could be related to there being more light incoming from that half of the moon as Saturn V cuts it into a larger and smaller half, in other words that the phenomena is stronger on the side of a stronger incoming light.

Just some thoughts. Love your vids always Destin. Peace :D

I'm pretty sure that this in an aberration caused by the aperature in the lense. Remember that all light from every angle enters the lense. It's up to the elements on either side of the aperature to gather the correct light pointing to a single point source. A brighter light can overpower the light that it's supposed to be gathering. The diffraction of that light around the small hole is augmented by the aspherical lens elements. Most lenses are aspherical - shaping a round light entering the lens into a rectangular exposure frame. The key word is rectangular. The horizontal direction is treated differently than vertical.

Technically that wasn't a blue moon, the original definition was the third full moon in a season with four full moons, the second full moon in one month definition was a misconception, though, since this version has been in widespread and popular use for several decades, both versions are, regrettably, correct. I guess the misconception does make spotting a blue moon easier, as the old seasons are confusing to follow, my general rule of thumb is that Winter begins with December and ends with February, Spring begins with March and ends with May, Summer begins with June and ends with August, and Fall begins with September and ends with November, allotting three months to each. By my following of the mathematical seasons, rather than observational seasons, this blue moon makes me happy as it falls on a date that satisfies both definitions of the term.

The line is precisely parallel with the camera frame edge ... it is an internal reflection that interferes with the light resulting in the inversion of the reflection ... the thickness of the line is the result of the thickness of the camera’s internal baffle.

You can duplicate this to prove it ... use a light table with opaque paper covering it where the paper has a cutout similar to the crescent moon.

Position your model in front using a red LED for the light on the escape rocket.

Align and photograph them at night and the reflection should react similarly.

You may need to use the same camera and lens and exposure settings ( or perhaps not)?

There was a similar problem/defect with a Nikon camera a couple of years ago. Internal reflections causing shadow lines but they fixed it by painting the baffle edge with non reflective black paint, I think?

I don't know the exact atmospheric conditions on that day, but it seems to me that it was rather dry and high pressure day. I have experienced a similar effect years ago while doing electrostatic experiments with pointed objects (ion emitters) while outside, visible with the naked eye. Take this with a grain of salt in any case - I am not implying this to be the answer to this particular situation but merely suggesting what may be involved in the effect but without knowing the exact conditions of course makes it mere speculation. The saturn rocket mockup is a large metallic structure exposed vertically; on a dry day any metallic structure builds up a rather noteable electrostatic charge (especially if painted/isolated externally hence coated with a dielectric) due to sole air friction on the structure (electrons being lost or gained). If this structure is not properly earthed the buildup can be several tens of Kilovolts reaching the hundreds based on the atmospheric conditions. The point, whether conductive or not would become a high charge accumulation area which due to dry weather would not dissipate it's charge very quickly. This would affect the air around that point causing a polarization effect on the light (gradient) not pointing away from the source but equipotentially (horizontally or on a plane, similar to an EM radiation source such as a GHz wave antenna with millimeter short wavelength). This distortion is more or less visible based on the kind of optics used and the coating on your lenses (UV, scratch protection, glare filter) and it is also visible with the naked eye depending on lighting conditions. It is more visible on the lower light / IR spectrum as the air absorbs this spectrum (when excited) more than UV (may even influence Rayleigh scattering at a distance), hence creating a darker absorbption line. Looking through any DSLR camera is equivalent to looking through any optics (until the shutter and mirror are not operated) meaning that optics and optical filters come into play and may enhance any polarization effect even if there is no specific polarization filter used respect to the naked eye. The atmosphere becomes a polarized filter at certain moments of the day (dawn, sunset) apart from creating noteable light diffraction effects (ex. enlarging the sun and moon setting on the horizon). Considering the above, combining both of these conditions which were present the evening you took those shots, would certainly have created interesting optical effects. Adding to that the fact that the moon was reflecting an already "preconditioned" atmospherically filtered sunlight (towards the IR spectrum) from our earth's partial shadow, I must say all these conditions were rather unique and unprecedented.
Having said this, the effect is intriguing to say the least and the shots you took are spectacular. Cheers!

Some sensors can create crazy artifacts. Look at camera moire etc. I am an astrophotographer. I see things like this everyday.  Consumer cameras have many in camera processes to make sense and clear artifacts. Sometimes they will mistake real data with an artifact and remove the data. Look at the "star eater" algorithm in Sony cameras. Low light photography is the most challenging that push these cameras to their limits. You may also look at what we call hot columns. They will start at a point light source and bleed across the entire sensor.  The light at the tip of the rocket is a good example. If I had to guess what happened I would say the sensor produced a hot column at the light. The processor picked it up and tried to replace the values in that line from the nearby pixels and couldn't get it right.

My guess is that it is a phenomenon caused by the CCD detector.  The flashing light at the tip of the rocket is so much brighter than the moonlight in the background that it causes a contrast issue with that line of CCD data.  My observation of your photos shows the line only appearing to one side of the tip of the rocket, not the other side.  Could it be that once that line of CCD charge was sensed by the CCD current detector that for the rest of that line the current detector was saturated and unable to correctly measure the actual amount of light being read off the remainder of capacitors in that row? If you had rotated the camera while you were observing the phenomenon, and observed that the line rotated, then you could have confirmed that the cause was the CCD detector.

Its not likely top be an interference phenomenon because:
* Interference patterns appear in "real" images (what you can catch with a screen). The camera acts more or less as a point on the screen looking at the potential interference source (slit/hole/pin). It would not see an interference pattern itself, only simply a bright or dark interference source.
* Interference pattern are 2D-fourier transformations of the lightsource (slit creates a line, ponints create circles). If the tip (point) would be the cause, the effect should be circular.
* The effect should appear on both shooting locations.
* the line should be perfectly orthogonal to a structure its is caused by, but its not orthogonal to the Saturn Antenna

I have a theory:
There probably is a light on the tip of the model rocket, probably a red one. My opinion, is that the reflective surface in or/and around the lamp is reflecting the the light coming off of the SBBM through that red filter. Given the fact that this surface isn't perfectly plane or oriented upwards, the reflected light appears as a line to far away observers.
Since this light is dimmer, and redder than the light coming off of the SBBM, it appears as a "dark" line, even though it's just darker line than the moon behind it, but not dark by itself. One way to check it would be to measure the colour of points on that line numerically.

This dark band is not caused by a diffraction imprint or a Fourier transform due to interaction of moon light with the tip of the rocket (or its aviation warning light apparatus). No alternating bands were seen. How can there be destructive interference without constructive interference?  For the phenomenon of diffraction imprint to occur, a point or linear source of light waves is needed. However, the moon does not serve as an effective point source.  

The reason that daylight shadows on the ground have slightly fuzzy or indistinct borders is due to the fact that the sun is not an effective point source. In the sky, the width of the moon occupies approximates the same number of arc seconds as the sun, hence, the same level of fuzziness, thus, not an effective point source. I do not believe that the rocket tip caused a diffraction imprint. The evidence does not point in that direction.

By the process of elimination, that leaves atmospheric diffraction as the cause of the dark line. In the video, the dark line varied somewhat, frame-to-frame, consistent with atmospheric diffraction. That would get my vote.

When reflecting telescopes view stars, the support arms for the forward mirror disrupts the light making the stars appear to have points coming off of them. Perhaps, since the object blocking the light was further away and taking up less FOV than the light source, it created a line of darkness from the object rather than lines of light coming from the light source.

I'd like to add that the number of support arms determines how many "rays" are in the final image (3 arms, 3 points; 5 arms, 5 points). Since the tip of the rocket was the blocking object, it would stand to reason that there would be only one line, or a series tiny dots that only look like a line.

Digital Camera AGC. Automatic gain control.software controlled and averaged with FT.Fourier Transform. Relatively bright moon background with darker rocket in the foreground . Tip of rocket covers one pixel. upsets the average on that row. Gain lowered. Next row or rows are averaged in and the wider tip averages more pixels .The rocket tip is approximately the same relative magnitude as the background lighting around the moon. My guess would be it's an optic lens distortion caused by the lenses themselves. OR because when an image is seen through a series of lenses it passes a point where it flips upside down or mirrors - for this to happen the image has to cross over itself and the image becomes so small that it basically becomes a beam of light (and since it's such a low intensity) the light waves in that image can interfere with each other - as wavelengths of different colours oscillate at different lengths - a band of one wavelength could in theory "jump" or wave over into another colours wavelength and "block" the corresponding area which that interfering wavelength overlaps onto.
Also the distortion was seen on both cameras through the lenses alone (bypassing the camera's internal imaging) & it seems that both telescopic lenses used look similar if not the same so it could be a design flaw. However if it is in fact a lens issue then you should be able to reproduce the distortion again filming a similar backdrop. Great experiment for a future video.

Ok, Just a theory, but here goes:

Diffraction seems to be a part of likely reason, but it is not the only interaction in force here - this will need experimental proving, but...
A point source of the line tells me that if it is diffraction, the line would not necessarily be parallel to the ground. The second interaction potentially comes from the polarisation of light - you have to bear in mind that the light travelling to the camera lens has passed through the atmosphere twice - once from the sun to the moon, and once back from the moon to the camera. Atmospheric/cloud based reflections could potentially be causing light polarisation, with horizontal polarisation being permissed.

As a result of this, the diffraction line happens to be occurring for light in the opposite polarisation to which is being allowed through, and therefore appears as a darker line, rather than a brighter one.

So, I think that it has to do with the physical obstruction caused by the actual beacon light assembly atop the rocket. The line is diminished, but not eliminated when the light is shining at the observer.
My thought is that the airflow between the rocket and the tower (although possibly a wider effect) is acting as a polarizing screen. The light shining from the moon is therefore striated horizontally.
The obstruction of the beacon assembly lessens the light available in that striation.
If the light from the upper part of the beacon and the obstruction of the mounting assembly sit in different but adjacent striations, then no matter how brightly the beacon shines, it will not illuminate the area darkened by the assembly.

There are 2 things to take note of

1. The line appears at the tip of the rocket, hence, it only happen at pointed object, this must relate to a diffraction phenomenon
2. The line is perfectly parallel to the sensor's edge, but could be perfectly parallel to the ground or perfectly perpendicular to the rocket. As we know, light doesn't care about the rocket direction nor does it care about the ground (especially those photons at the pointed tip) so that left the line being perfectly parallel to the edge of the picture (or the sensor)
3. Why is the line not parallel to the vertical edge of the photo but horizontal edge? This points me to the rolling shutter effect of CMOS camera.

So my best educated guess is the light got diffracted at the pointed tip of the rocket and the rolling shutter effect if the CMOS camera pick it up and form a slightly darker line

To everyone who is saying power lines: remember that the top of the rocket is 300 feet plus a little above the ground. Destin is 60 feet up. That means that for these to be power lines in front of the Moon we can figure out a general elevation for them. If they are behind the rocket as some suggest they would have to be over 300 feet above the ground since he is looking at an upward angle. No power line pole or tower is 300 feet tall. A radio antenna yes but not the tower for a power line. Even high voltage line towers are generally only 100 to 150 feet tall. There are some taller ones but these are special purpose like ones which bridge over big gaps like a canyon, etc.
Bottom line: it's not power lines. The upward view angle and position of the line rule it out

I work with CCD in my lab, and I have seen this effect in laser ablation pictures, a very bright small region. At a given gain, due to the overall intensity, the light of the rocket saturates the pixels on that line, because it is the way CCD works, a charge transfer, from one bucket (pixel) the the next one.

Let's debunk at least one theory, that this is a contrail from an aircraft:

So, let's compile what we know:
Destin's point of view was 60 feet above ground level. The elevation at his location is 633 feet MSL, so we'll call Zd the height of Destin above sea level, 693 feet.

The Saturn 5 is assumed to be the same height as an actual Saturn 5 at 363 feet. The elevation at the Saturn 5 is 673 feet, so we'll call Zs the height of the tip of the Saturn 5 rocket above sea level: 1,036 feet.

Zd = 633 + 60 = 693 ft
Zs = 673 + 363 = 1036 ft

From this, we can determine the difference in absolute elevation:

Δz = 343 ft

We also know that the distance between Destin and the Saturn 5 is 11,701.54 feet, which we'll assign to d.

And from there, we can calculate the vertical angle from Destin's position to the tip of the Saturn 5:

θds = tan(Δz / d) = tan(343 / 11701.54) = 1.68°

Let's assume any contrails occur between 15,000 feet and 40,000 feet MSL. From the angle Destin to the tip of the Saturn 5, we can extrapolate a minimum and maximum distance of any aircraft that may be causing the contrails:

Dmin = 15000 / atan(1.68°) = 511,700 feet = 96.91 miles
Dmin = 40000 / atan(1.68°) = 1,365,000 feet = 258.5 miles

At 06:35 (12:35 UTC), there were several aircraft in the vicinity that flew past the line extrapolated from Destin's position: JIA5081, AAL93, SWA1658, SWA497, and other miscellaneous flights. However, after examining each flight profile (using the intersection of the flight path with the extrapolated line of sight, then using d * atan(1.68 degrees) to determine expected altitude), none of these aircraft come even close to the extrapolated line, even accounting for variations in viewing angle, flight path deviations, and other environmental factors.

Just from this, I can conclude that (provided there were no other aircraft that FlightRadar24 didn't see) this line is not a contrail. There must be some other phenominon causing this. My first thought was a very distant contrail. Any airliners flying at cruising altitude that low in the horizon may not be very visible in the twilight, and it could have flown past quite some time earlier. Another thought would be a lingering dust trail from a meteor, which could have easily been missed or too dim to be seen in the twilight. Either way, the idea I'm getting is that it's a very high altitude trail in the atmosphere, as anything floating around closer certainly would have had more apparent movement.

I think it is unlikely to have anything to do with the cameras (e.g. lenses) considering 3 cameras saw it at the same spot in the scene. Also doesn't appear it would be anything ground-based like powerlines given the vantage point (only nearby power lines would appear that high over the trees) and how it's not visible at all until the moon goes behind it.

Just my amateur analysis, I'm no expert.

On another note, I lived in and around Huntsville in 1995-2000 and the RV park next to the Space & Rocket Center for several months around 1996. I enjoyed my time there and would like to visit again now that I'm grown up with a deeper understanding and appreciation for space and science.

A transmission tower or power tower(electricity pylon in the United Kingdom, Canada and parts of Europe) is a tall structure, usually a steel lattice tower, used to support an overhead power line.

Transmission tower￼

A transmission tower

Typestructure, lattice tower and overhead power lineFirst production20th century

They are used in high-voltage AC and DC systems, and come in a wide variety of shapes and sizes. Typical height ranges from 15 to 55 m (49 to 180 ft),[1] though the tallest are the 370 m (1,214 ft) towers of a 2,700 m (8,858 ft) span of Zhoushan Island Overhead Powerline Tie. In addition to steel, other materials may be used, including concrete and wood

Before you comment about digital camera image artifacts caused by the light at the top of the rocket, understand that with a DSLR (Digital Single Lens Reflex) camera, the photographer is viewing through the lens - NOT by way of the imaging sensor. Basically, Destin is viewing the scene through an optical telescope. The only thing between Destin's eye and the lens is a mirror that acts as the shutter. When the photo is taken, the mirror moves out of the way so the sensor has full, unobstructed light. This works the same way for an SLR camera using photo sensitive film also. If the line is caused by micro scratches on the mirror, it would not show up in the image. If it was a digital image artifact, Destin would not see it in the view-finder. The common objects used by both Destin and the imaging sensor is the lens itself, and of course the atmosphere and optics going on in the scene. It could be a lens artifact, but Destin has commented that it showed up in two other cameras. The odds of all three lenses having the same cleaning smudges are almost impossible. Besides, the line would "shimmer" as the lens/camera is moved if it was a smudge or micro-scratches on the lens.

P.S. It's not the light on the tip of the escape tower causing it. That's an aircraft avoidance light which flashes for about 2 seconds every 5 or 6 seconds. The line is there when the light is off.

One very possible explanation could be atmospheric refraction. The weather conditions that day might have caused some refraction to occur at, what seems to be the tip of the launch escape system, causing the line to appear on the moon.
Here's an example of the distortion atmospheric refraction can cause:
https://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap050826.html
Here's the "line" effect (look at the last two moons, taken when the skies are clear; the first few are covered by clouds, but the last two are not as the skies around them are clear):
https://media3.s-nbcnews.com/j/streams/2013/july/130720/6c8321753-130720-science-moon.nbcnews-ux-2880-1000.jpg
Finally, at around 1:07 - 1:10, if you slow the video down and look carefully at the moon passing through the rocket, you can see the moon being unevenly shifted because of refraction (no line though).
It would have been better if you took the moon from different angles (vertically speaking).

Notice, the color of the line matches the surrounding sky (this dark blue is really the foreground color injected by scattering between you and the moon). This implies that the line occurs at significant distance relative to even the rocket. The slope of the line seems to match the slope of the ground, so it would make sense for it to be an "altitude" based phenomena.

Could this be a density/internal reflection thing? The moon light (which has been reduced to the red wavelength) is shining through a thin layer of atmosphere with a sharp change in density due to the early morning calm or a sharp temperature inversion (perhaps from an invisible layer of condensation). A line of light is getting caught in this density shift where it experiences total internal reflection (like planar sheet of fiber-optic cable). It then follows the curvature of the layer exactly, unable to escape and shine through. Only light entering at the critical angle gets caught, sub critical angles are refracted and super critical angles are reflected and are invisible. The half of the moon visible the below the line is actually bending up from the denser air below the density discontinuity (having entered at a sub critical angle, then refracted), but the two images don't quite match up and so we see the line. The redness may be a factor here too: due to the light being mostly red, there is only one critical angle, instead of a continuous spectrum (which would have resulted in a blending of colors across multiple lines... softening the effect and spreading it out over the image). This is kind of like how the moon/sun are egg shaped near sunset. But you never see a line at sun set because the sun light is too hot to leave the air calm and still like you find just before sunrise.

If I'm right, you'd expect to see this again if the air is calm and/or there's a sharp density shift at altitude. But you'd have to look for it just before sunrise before the air starts to churn. So it may be a fluke of you capturing a red moon set on a calm morning.

I believe that it likely  has something to do with the significant contrast differential between the background lighting level of the moon in the shot and the tip of the rocket both with the red light ON and the red light OFF (the moon in background is roughly either twice as bright as tip with light off and roughly half as bright when the light is on)? I know that the different imaging sensors and methods for capturing the photonic loads on each pixel per shutter cycle can cause image aberrations in the captured image. These photographic anomalies are usually seen in horizontal scan lines  used in recording interlaced video, but can be seen in multi-process resultant images caused from either camera sensor capture method then passed to the camera internal image processing then stored to disk. This photographic artifacting is called "stepping" (not to be confused with "color banding") and is also usually indicative of a line scanning camera mode and also usually seen more during low lighting levels as this is where the "noise" is higher due to the straining of the camera sensor pixels to capture low light during the allowed light collection time of the shutter speed or frame rate (no shuttering). As you are usually shooting video for your channel, were you shooting in video mode or trying to get an actual still photo? As you were shooting in lower light, and the lights were on at the Rocket Center and driven at US standard 60Hz, do you think that there was a rolling strobe effect due to the camera shutter likely being higher (even slightly) than the 60Hz of the lighting of the tip of the rocket?

My best guess is an inversion layer. This is very likely to occur in early morning hours in calm weather. Where the layers meet would look like two piece of glass with different refractive indexes, and a line between the two if your viewing edge-on, as you were.

You could possibly confirm this by comparing one frame to the next after passing it through an edge-detection filter, and check for a subtle change in the circular shape of the moon as it passes between layers. This could be done in Photoshop. The photos would have to be perfectly registered with several points on the moon, and you might be looking for changes that are sub-pixel widths. A Difference filter would look like an arc growing from beneath the line.

I believe it is light diffracting around some small object at the tip. Light diffracts around objects much like it does through a double slit. A point of light from behind the rocket would result in a maximum at your location, not a minimum. In this case though, the moon is much larger than the tip of the rocket, making point like assumptions not valid. As a result, the light from the moon left and right of the rocket tip may destructively interfer at your location. I did some calcs in my head and got minima and maxima widths of the order of single meters assuming you were about 10 km away from the rocket.

What is hard to explain using diffraction is why the line seems to be at an angle. The angle of the diffraction should be perpendicular to the linear object it is diffracting around. Unless the tip of the rocket is at some slight angle, I can’t explain the angle of the diffraction line going across the screen.

You would have to do the calculations knowing your distances and the measurements of the tip of the rocket.

Even some destructive interference should show up pretty dark relative to the intensity of undiffracted light elsewhere

It's too bad the photo is slightly out of focus. :(  Without much more detail than that, it's really hard to say, but I think the answer that makes the most sense would be contrail.  What makes you so sure that it wasn't?  With a rough scale model made in SketchUp of all the distances involved (height photo was taken from, height of rocket, difference in elevation between church parking lot and base of rocket, distance from parking lot to rocket), a plane being where it is in your photos at an altitude of 30,000 ft. would put it 144 miles away.  At that distance, with that much air between you and the contrail and without it being illuminated, a contrail would be invisible until the moon went behind it. Although I don't have a precise explanation, I expect it is due to how a CCD camera is "read" by its electronics.  The "read" operation is a lot like a bucket-brigade.  The charge in one pixel is dumped into the next pixel in its row (or column) until it reaches the end or the row (or column), where it is read by the electronics.  An excess of charge in one pixel can overflow into adjacent pixels.  Most definitely, the line is not "on the Moon".
Same reason why stars photographed through a telescope with a support cross look like they have 4 rays poking out. Remember you're working with lenses and mirrors.

I was in college at SUNY Albany, waiting for a bus at the uptown campus. To the north was the full moon. At one point, I looked up and saw a straight black line laid across the moon as if someone had drawn an equator on it.

As we watched, this equator line slid slowly down the moon until it disappeared.

Several others alongside me saw this as well. We all looked at one another in confusion and wondered what it was that we had seen. We theorized, but nothing could be proven and our theories were not particularly strong.

Life went on.

Then one day, I was in the same place, and it must've been a month or two later, because the moon was full again. But it was not quite as late in the evening, and instead of a black sky, I saw the darkening blue sky of evening.

I also saw that same black line across the moon. It was doing that same slide down the face of the moon. No one else was around me though, and I had no one to discuss it with. Certainly not the same group of people who had randomly been assembled to see this the previous time.

There was one difference. Because the sky was not yet completely dark, I was able to see that to the left and right of the moon, that line continued!

IT WAS A VAPOR TRAIL FROM A JET AIRPLANE.

The explanation for its appearance of sliding down the moon's face was that the vapor trail was being gradually blown to the north, giving it a parallax illusion of "sliding down the moon."

I give you this example as a demonstration that there are times when we are not able to comprehend what we witness. Patience can sometimes be all that we need to eventually come to a state of comprehending. Sometimes, it's patience and investigation and inquisitiveness.

Why do you think that it's not Schlieren? It could ABSOLUTELY be Schlieren. You have a light source (the Sun) behind the camera, the rocket is cutting off part of the light source (like a razor blade or whatever does in Schlieren imaging), and the moon is effectively at infinite distance making the position of the camera basically irrelevant. So minute differences in the density of the air are projected on the moon, but only in 2 dimensions, because it's a point, not a plane cutting off the light.

I think it has to do with diffraction:

Babinet's principle tells us we can invert it to considering everything blocked except for a sliver which is the tip of the rocket and resulting pattern is the exact same (except at the centre)

We have therefore a top hat function as our aperture and as this is far field we use a Fraunhofer approx for the diffraction pattern which is a sinc function. The sinc function has zero intensities every 7microradians while your camera can about cover an angle of 30microradians. Over this relative large distance the intensity has decayed a lot hence you see a dark line and cant really resolve the minimums and maximums of the diffraction pattern!

I have tweeted the maths to you Destin! What are your thought?!?

Given that there was no wind in the video, I have a pretty good guess. The model rocket was slightly warmer than the ambient temperature, causing it to be encompassed in a thin layer of warm air. This air rose slowly up the surface of the rocket until it reached the tip, at which point the it cooled to equalize with the surrounding air. It then spread out as a thin disk, and the water vapor condensed creating a thin, barely visible circular cloud or fog around the tip of the model rocket. You viewed this fog on its edge, causing it to appear as a straight line obstructing your view of the moon.

Some wild guess here.. Which might make sense..
The moon is very far obviously, so any light rays coming from it is in a good probability to be parallel.
That cylinder is blocking the light vertically.. Therefore it can be considered as a mask.
As you might know of the Fourier plane, that plane is located at an infinite distance from the mask, which in your case is an excellent approximation for the distance from the rocket.
At the Fourier plane the mask is 90 degrees to the physical mask.. Therefore it will create a horizontal shading for a vertical mask..

I would imagine that the lens on the beacon light you can see at the top of the rocket could be creating a fresnel effect (think linear not spherical). I worked with fresnel lenses in the military on a FLOLS, Fresnel Lens Optical Landing System (they give aircraft a visual reference for how far above or below the optimal glide path they are on landing) and it creates a horizontal beam of light that almost looks like what you are seeing except in this case it appears to be shifting the color of the light being viewed resulting in what looks like a horizontal line of shadow.

The vibrations combined with the amount of air the light traveled through to your camera could have created an atmospheric line.... it does seem to bounce around a bit.

My random stab guess at an answer is that you are right about its being a mirage. I think I saw in your earlier footage a number of horizontal features appearing across the face of the moon, and it looked like the edge of the moon's image was also wavey in a similar way. Just checked - the effect appears at 1:05 as you're showing the rising moon - just its normal full self. There are no lines evident as such, but the edge of the image is notched, and it looks like the notches line up edge-to-edge horizontally across the moon's image. My guess is that the alignment with the top of the rocket was accidental, which would fit with the same effect not showing up from a different location. If the air high up where you were filming was relatively calm with little to no convection going on, I could imagine that the temperature variations would become stratified at night, similar to the situation in the stratosphere (or for that matter the effect could be arising in the stratosphere, since you are looking through it). The variation in temperature would of course lead to a variation in refractive index of the light and hey presto! mirage effect. Filming on a cold night may be a factor?

This is just a hypothesis, but I think it has something to do with the fact that there is a red light at the top of the rocket which probably has a red-transparent, vetrically oriented, cylindrical casing around it. The light emitted from the moon passes through the casing and spreads out horizonally in a flat plane (looks like a horizontal line viewed from head on). Then when the red light from the moon and the red light from this plane meet they destructively interfere in that plane, creating a darker line. This, I think, is only possible when the light of both are close to the same wavelength.

Another option is that the casing from the light at the top is colorless-transparent, but offsets the wavelengths of red light coming from the moon exactly so that it destructively interferes with the red light passing through the plane. This keeps the wavelengths coming through the case and going past the case the same and therefore making destructive interference more pronounced.

Let me know what you think.
